pullRequest.title: GH-2011 merge strategy and checklist added to PR template
pullRequest.bodyText:
GitHub issue resolved: #2011 
Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

added PR author checklist (not required for people to check things off, more a reminder)
added a note about our default merge strategy being squash and merge
added a link to the developer documentation that goes into more detail about our merge strategy.

commit.message:
GH-2011 explain merge strategy in PR template

- added checklist to help authors
- added links to more detailed explanation of merge strategy on website
GH-2011 PR checklist and merge strategy added to template

nodes.bodyText: From having added a checklist like this in one of my previous projects I don't belive that it actually works as a checklist. We can always try, but I think it would work just as well as a regular list.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -4,6 +4,15 @@ GitHub issue resolved: # <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. This lin
 
 Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:
 
-* 
-* 
-* 
+<!-- short description of your change goes here -->
+
+---- 
+PR Author Checklist: 
+
+ - [ ] my pull request is [self-contained](https://rdf4j.org/documentation/developer/merge-strategy/#self-contained-changes-pull-requests-and-commits)
+ - [ ] I've added tests for the changes I made
+ - [ ] every commit message starts with the issue number (GH-xxxx) followed by a meaningful description of the change
+ - [ ] every commit has been [signed off](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1962094/what-is-the-sign-off-feature-in-git-for)

commit.message:
GH-2011 PR description no longer auto-closes issue

This will not work with squash and merge strategy because PR description
does not end up in the commit message (which is what triggers
auto-close).

nodes.bodyText: I'm not 100% sure but I believe auto-closing the issue may no longer work when using squash and merge because the PR description won't end up in the commit message. This is how auto-closing of issues worked in the past. It might still work though based on whether the PR is actually linked to an issue (which is a feature Github introduced very recently). In any case, I'm taking it out for brevity - if it still works that's great, if not, we're not misleading people.
nodes.diffHunk:

-GitHub issue resolved: # <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. This line 
-                              automatically closes the issue when the PR is merged --> 
+GitHub issue resolved: # <!-- add a Github issue number here, e.g #123. -->
